item.content:encoded:
Hi folks,

I wanted to finally start my exchange “diary” (which is more likely an exchange blog) yet before I return from India, where I am doing my exchange, back to Slovakia.
As an exchange student, I made two major mistakes, which you as future exchange students should be aware of, so I will describe them little more.

A diary

What I regret the most, and what no sane exchange student should not forget, or be lazy, to do, is taking a diary. Firstly when you arrive to your host country, everything will be new to you, you will excited of everything and you will gain lots and lots of experience. Sadly, those days your memories won’t last too long, because there will be constantly coming more and more experiences and discoveries to you. That time, if you don’t take a diary, íf you don’t write down everything immidiately or at least you don’t sit in the evening to make a romance-size note of your lovely passed day, your memories will be lost, or at the best case blurred.

I went for my exchange irresponsibly if not punishably unprepared and after coming to India I was so excited, that I didn’t even think of taking a diary.

So the very first rule: Whatever happens, whatever small experience you get in the first months of your exchange, please take down a note of everything whatever the fuck happens to you.

Lot of photos

Another thing was, kinda technical in my case, that I didn’t use my money in the right way and again, I must repeat, I went for my exchange absolutely technicaly unprepared – shitty old phone with constantly discharged battery and fucking low quality camera. Because of these circumstances, I wasn’t actually much interested in taking photos – these were most of the time ugly, blurred or shaded. So even things I didn’t take down in my hypothetical diary, nor took I any photos of these (or, if I remember correctly, very few), so all my memories just dissolved. What a hammer.

The second rule is clear: Nothing electronical you buy before your exchange is more valuable than a good camera, or at least smartphone having good camera (later I got one in India itself because of the South India Tour, which I will tell you about once later).

Conclusion (TL;DR)

Exchange is the most valuable experience in your life. Nothing is more valuable: going until college with As nor your first sex. You will understand this once you’re on and once you return from an exchange. So, don’t waste your exchange year, it is unique and you won’t be able to go through something similar once again. Please:

  • Take an exchange diary, write down your detailed feelings and experiences.
  • Take a lot of photos while you find things around you interesting. After a half of your exchange year everything around you will become very normal to you.

item.title: went-sleep.php
item.description: went-sleep.php is a little utility written in PHP, which is supposed to help me with going regularly early to sleep<
item.content:encoded:
went-sleep.php is a little utility written in PHP, which is supposed to help me with going regularly early to sleep
during the extraordinary days (those are, at least for me, mostly when I write some code which I am totally excited
with, so it happens to me that I am finishing and further improving it long to the night – often till 2 am or 3 am).

Busy mind doesn’t allow you sleep

Running went-sleep.php should be the last thing, except brushing your teeth and tidying away the computer, which is
done before you go to sleep. Why? If you were doing something long to the night, you (and your mind) got pretty
engaged into it. So now even if you switch off the lights, lie in the bed and close your eyes, your mind will stay busy
collecting and ordering the information about what you just right now finished doing. So you won’t be able to sleep
and you will keep getting thoughts about how to improve the stuff you have just finished and, what’s worse, you will
actively start thinking and participate in solving the ideas in these thoughts!

That’s when you should run went-sleep.php. You will issue a simple command (went-sleep.php), which you should type
to the console yourself – to strenghten your whole concentration to it. The command runs and greets you a Goodnight.

Now that your mind is fully concentrated on what you’ve just done (this time running a simple command), it can
easily sort it out and then switch to passive mode (that’s when you’re sleeping; your mind keeps sorting the earlier
information from that day but without thoughts).

Running it

Running went-sleep.php is as simple as running it itself:

This simple piece of code records current UNIX timestamp at the time of running, which includes current date & time;
current timezone (you can also specify the timezone yourself in the config file, but about that later)
and the current goal for this day, which is just the time you wanted to regularly get to bed.
However, the goal is most often the same, so you can just set it in the config.

If you need to add an exception to the time you aim go to sleep for a particular day, just add the --goal arg:

…and it will show you how much did you achieve your goals overtime.
